statute_citation: N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law 899-aa; N.Y. State Tech. Law 208
personal_information_definition: First name or initial + last name combined with: SSN, driver's license number or non-driver ID card number, financial account number or credit/debit card number (with or without access code if account could be accessed)
Username or email address combined with password or security question and answer
Biometric information (fingerprint, voice print, retina image, other unique physical or digital representation)
HIPAA-covered medical information or health insurance information
breach_definition: Unauthorized acquisition or access of computerized data that compromises the security, confidentiality, or integrity of private information maintained by a business. Good faith acquisition by employee or agent is not a breach if information is not used or further disclosed.
encryption_safe_harbor_details: No notification required if data elements were encrypted and the encryption key was not also acquired. Applies to data that was encrypted, redacted, or otherwise rendered unusable.
notification_timeline: In the most expedient time possible and without unreasonable delay

other_agencies: New York State Division of State Police
New York Department of State (Division of Consumer Protection)

notification_content_requirements: Contact information for the person or business making the notification
Telephone numbers and websites for the three major credit reporting agencies
Toll-free number and website for the FTC
Toll-free number, website, and address for the New York AG's office and the Division of State Police
Description of the categories of information believed to have been compromised
Description of the breach incident in general terms
penalties: AG enforcement with civil penalties up to $5,000 per violation (up to $150,000 total). Private right of action: actual damages or $50 minimum damages per instance, plus reasonable attorney fees. Court may treble damages up to $1,000 per instance for knowing or reckless violations.
special_provisions: Must notify AG, State Police, and Division of Consumer Protection within specified timeline regardless of number affected (no threshold)
The SHIELD Act (2020) expanded definition of private information and broadened applicability to any person or business that owns or licenses data of NY residents
Reasonable security safeguards requirement (administrative, technical, and physical) codified in the SHIELD Act
Substitute notice allowed if cost exceeds $250,000, or affected class exceeds 500,000, or entity does not have sufficient contact information
